column4: anyone know if I install the fglrx ATI gfx drivers using apt, it should overwrite or remove the corresponding Mesa libraries ?
it does divert them using dpkg-divert
is there something I have to do manually, because it still seems to be loading the Mesa libs... was wondering what I was doing wrong...
do dpkg-divert --list, it should list diversion of /usr/X11R6/lib/libGL.so.1.2 to /usr/share/fglrx/diversions/libGL.so.1.2 by fglrx-driver
and if not ?
then look in /var/lib/dpkg/info/fglrx-driver.preinst
thanks... will do.
I see the diversion listed, but it's still loading the Mesa Lib...
how big it is? it should be 658984 bytes if it's diverted
yep, that's exactly how it should be... (try uninstalling fglrx-driver if you don't believe :-)
try running fgl_glxgears
anyway, how do you know that it is not working?
slow 3d and the results of fglrxinfo
and have you changed XFree96Config to use fglrx driver?
do lsmod | grep fglrx
there should be lot info starting with fglrx
noprob.  I was fighting to get it work before...
if you want to know, the issue ended up that I was using the included ATI AGP support,
strange it should work too (but I am using kernel version, because I think it's newer...)
not sure... it's an nforce chipset if that matters...
ahh, I think that ATI is using some older version of AGP code and support for nforce is relatively new
but the bottom line is that it works now, so I can continue to explore... thanks for all your hrlp.
